oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Grand Concert," St. Andrew Chapel program
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One page program detailing a "Grand Concert" to be given in benefit of St. Andrew Chapel's Sunday School. Performers are listed on the program.

The AMEC grew out of the Free African Society (FAS) which Richard Allen, Absalom Jones, and others established in Philadelphia in 1787. The most significant era of denominational development occurred during the Civil War and Reconstruction. Oftentimes, with the permission of Union army officials AME clergy moved into the states of the collapsing Confederacy. By 1880 there was estimated to be 400,000 members in the Southern states.
